column4: Gini coefficient
column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).

column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: This is the income or expenditure of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total income or expenditure.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: P90 is the the level of income or expenditure below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income or expenditure below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: P90 is the the level of income or expenditure above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income or expenditure below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: P50 is the median – the level of income or expenditure below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income or expenditure below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column4: Palma ratio
column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income or expenditure of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

Inequality Data Explorer of World Bank d: Relative poverty: Share of people below 40% of the median
column4: Share in poverty (< 40% of the median)
column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 40% of the median income or expenditure.
column8: This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. It is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices.
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column4: Mean log deviation
column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal.
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

column4: Polarization index
column5: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
column7: The polarization index, also known as the Wolfson polarization index, measures the extent to which the distribution of income or expenditure is “spread out” and bi-modal. Like the Gini coefficient, the polarization index ranges from 0 (no polarization) to 1 (complete polarization).
column8: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
column9: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

Inequality Data Explorer of World Bank d: Share of the richest decile in total expenditure
column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: The expenditure of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total expenditure.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP)

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: P90 is the the level of expenditure below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of expenditure below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP), adapted by Our World in Data.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: P90 is the the level of expenditure above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of expenditure below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP), adapted by Our World in Data.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: P50 is the median – the level of expenditure below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of expenditure below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP), adapted by Our World in Data.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total expenditure of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP), adapted by Our World in Data.

Inequality Data Explorer of World Bank d: 60% of median - share of population below poverty line
column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: % of population living in households with an expenditure per person below 60% of the median.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP), adapted by Our World in Data.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal. The measure is also referred to as 'Theil L' or 'GE(0)', in reference to the wider families of inequality measures to which the MLD belongs.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP)

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
column5: The polarization index, also known as the Wolfson polarization index, measures the extent to which the distribution of expenditure is “spread out” and bi-modal. Like the Gini coefficient, the polarization index ranges from 0 (no polarization) to 1 (complete polarization). The polarization index is based on Wolfson (1994) and Ravallion and Chen (1997). See Wolfson, Michael C. 1994. “When Inequalities Diverge.” The American Economic Review 84 (2): 353–58. https://www.jstor.org/stable/2117858 and Ravallion, Martin, and Shaohua Chen. 1997. “What Can New Survey Data Tell Us about Recent Changes in Distribution and Poverty?” The World Bank Economic Review 11 (2): 357–82. https://www.jstor.org/stable/3990232.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP)
